metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Sons of Pandit Suraj Prasad Dubey

facts.text: In 1945, Pandit Suraj Prasad Dubey promised to donate Rs. 30,000 for construction of a women's hospital in memory of his deceased wife Gomti Devi, on condition of matching government contribution, construction through his agency, on approved site near Phoolmati Temple on Kannauj Makrand Nagar Road, according to approved plan.
Collector Shri Govind Narain accepted conditions, received donation cheques, foundation stone laid by Governor Sir Maurice Hallet in 1945 with Gomti Devi inscribed.
Dubey started collecting bricks for construction.
Govind Narain transferred, next Collector Shri Bhagwan Sahai wrote to Civil Surgeon in March 1946 noting delay.
District Supply Officer proposed to divert Dubey's collected bricks to school construction (Exhibits 18 and 19).
Dubey continued correspondence till his death in July 1947.
Post Dubey's death, no progress; plans changed, agency given up, no matching grant, foundation stone removed.
Sons sent reminder (Ex. A-6), government replied proposal under active consideration six years later.
Suit notice under s.80 CPC sent, no response.
After suit instituted, government constituted committee, new plan, built 22-bed hospital on same site.
Plaintiffs offered to withdraw suit if original undertaking substantially complied with and half costs paid.
Trial court decreed suit for Rs.30,000; High Court affirmed findings of fact and decree.
District Government Counsel admitted most terms except completion in near future.
Shri Govind Narain not examined as witness.
New foundation stone laying ceremony by Health Minister Shri C.B. Gupta; plaintiffs requested return of original stone.

legal_issues.text: Whether the donation of Rs.30,000 was an absolute gift or conditional upon specific terms including matching grant, construction by donor's agency, on approved site and plan, at early date.
Whether non-fulfillment of conditions resulted in failure of the gift and creation of resulting trust for return of money.
Applicability of cy pres doctrine to save the charity.
Whether plaintiffs estopped from claiming refund due to offers to withdraw suit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Donation was outright gift with general charitable intent; pious wishes did not make it conditional; non-fulfillment did not fail condition precedent.
Cy pres applies as general charitable purpose for hospital facilities; court may direct application to broad purpose.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: English precedents like In re Tutley; Indian Trusts Act s.83 (analogous)

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaintiffs agreed to withdraw claim upon new hospital built.

respondent_arguments.text: Donation conditional on specific terms: site, plan, agency, matching grant, early construction; all breached.
No general charitable intent; specific purpose failed ab initio; no cy pres.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner, Lucknow Division v. Deputy Commissioner of Partapgarh (PC)

respondent_arguments.text: No estoppel as offers not accepted; no final contract.

court_reasoning.text: Facts as found by trial court and affirmed by High Court: donation on specific terms proved by overwhelming evidence; no rebuttal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: All terms settled: site, name Gomti Devi, plan for maternity/child welfare, Rs.30,000 + matching, through Dubey's agency.

court_reasoning.text: Donation was conditional; conditions not fulfilled (no matching grant, no agency to Dubey, delays, changes); gift did not take effect.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Resulting trust in favour of donor; state mere custodian.

court_reasoning.text: No general charitable intention; specific object (6-bed hospital by Dubey on site); cy pres not applicable as gift failed ab initio.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Borderline but specific terms dominate; precedents like Ulverston Hospital support failure.

court_reasoning.text: No estoppel: offers by plaintiffs conditional, not accepted by government; mere correspondence, no final agreement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiffs paid full court fee; construction not on plaintiffs' assurance.

court_reasoning.text: Government litigation policy critiqued: should settle just claims, not abuse process.

holdings.text: Donation was conditional gift which failed due to non-fulfillment of conditions, resulting in resulting trust for refund.
Cy pres doctrine inapplicable as no general charitable intent and gift failed ab initio.

precedents_cited.relevance: Charitable gift definition difficult; hospital is charitable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nori Venkata Rama Dikshitulu v. Ravi Venkatappayya
precedents_cited.relevance: Cy pres for inter vivos gifts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Potti Swami v. Rao Saheb D. Govindarajulu
Commissioner, Lucknow Division v. Deputy Commissioner of Partapgarh
precedents_cited.relevance: Specific purpose subscriptions returnable if impracticable; no general intent.
Distinction general vs specific charity; specific fails if institution ceases.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re University of London Medical Sciences Institute Fund
precedents_cited.relevance: Conditional gifts to specific purpose; return if fails.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Ulverston and District New Hospital Building Trust
precedents_cited.relevance: No general intent for specific hospital fund; resulting trust.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harish Chandra v. Hindu Sharnam Sewak Mandal
precedents_cited.relevance: Conditional charitable gifts fail if impossible.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Trusts Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Reflects equity principle for resulting trusts; analogous though not directly applicable to public trusts.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Suit notice served; not effective in shaking government.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting depends on condition precedent; transfer fails if not fulfilled.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; decree of lower courts affirmed directing State of Uttar Pradesh to return Rs.30,000 to plaintiffs with costs.

key_quotes.text: The State is a virtuous litigant and looks with unconcern on immoral forensic successes.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: If the condition is never fulfilled, the estate never arises.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There is a distinction well settled by the authorities. There is one class of cases in which there is a gift to charity generally... There is another class, in which the testator shows an intention, not of general charity, but to give to some particular institution.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishing general vs specific charitable intent (from In re Rymer).
